text: I
I just assumed that because my child had
an illness that there would be help
available there's not Ferdinand Walker
the most devastating part of losing her
job of 14 years last December was not
the loss of income rather it was the
loss of health insurance for her 21 year
old son Jake the first thing that I'd
thought about of course is how am I
going to ensure that my child gets to go
to the doctor because he does have
cancer he is in remission now but he
does still have to have every three
months go to the doctor for check-ups if
unemployment caught them off guard Dana
and her husband Russ were even less
prepared for the Odyssey that followed
an agonizing search to find affordable
health care now six months after being
laid off they still have no health
insurance for themselves it's a familiar
situation for millions of newly
uninsured Americans who find themselves
one diagnosis away from medical and
financial ruin when you're used to
walking in and hitting somebody
twenty-dollar bill for a
two-hundred-dollar office visit yeah
it's different you realize how
vulnerable you really are Jake was
diagnosed with advanced testicular
cancer in 2005 he had started to be in
pain some the last few weeks before he
shared with us he was a big 18 year old
kid and president of his high school
Future Farmers of America club the world
was my doorstep I was just had
everything going for me and then
something's wrong it just wasn't cool he
came to me one night and told me that
one of his testicles was bigger than the
other and I said well I think that's
kind of normal he goes no mom it's a lot
bigger so we did go to the doctor the
very next day and he did have a ten
pound tumor in his abdomen it had
metastasized to his abdomen at the time
Jake was covered by his mother's
employer DHL delivery service and the
only concern was to get him the best
possible care over the next two years
Jake underwent to stem cell transplants
for surgeries in numerous chemotherapy
treatments but it wasn't enough in 2007
doctors gave him a twenty percent chance
of
survival my first thought was just
devastation you know this can't be
happening and then I got mad and I said
you know if you can't help him you find
me somebody that can and they sent us to
md anderson and we were met with the
doctor named lance pal arrow i estimated
his risk of recurrence to be a hundred
percent at MD Anderson Cancer Center in
Houston widely considered one of the top
cancer hospitals in the country dr.
Lance pagliaro gave Jake and
experimental regimen of chemotherapy
drugs as a last-gasp chance of
destroying the cancer he really helped
me out i'm pretty sure he saved my life
now three years after his diagnosis and
nearly 2 million dollars of medical care
later Jake is living cancer-free as a
junior at Oklahoma State University
could be a normal person now my hair is
going to grow back not going to be in a
crowd of people and you're not going to
be able to pick me out and say oh that
kid has cancer but while Jake enjoys a
return to normal life the fear of
recurrence remains a daily reality for
his family for at least the next two
years he requires regular monitoring
including CT scans blood tests and
x-rays that run thousands of dollars if
he can remain free of disease long
enough someday we hope we can pronounce
and cured now we are we're one year out
so obviously we're still within that two
to three years period where he's at risk
the day-to-day worried that the cancer
will come back is made worse by the
uncertainty of whether Jake would again
be able to get the care he needs in
December when Donna took Jake to md
anderson for a checkup she told hospital
administrators that she would likely be
losing her insurance I was certainly
concerned to hear that they might lose
their insurance we would not have been
able to do any of the the treatment that
we gave he didn't have insurance in all
Jake had received nearly two million
dollars in surgeries and treatment one
abdominal surgery cost about 300,000
dollars I had retro pernil lymph node
dissection quite a big ordeal and this
is my scar to deny him the relatively
inexpensive follow-up that is so crucial
to make sure that he continues to to
stay healthy you know to deny him that
just
absolutely no sense well dr. pagliaro
said that he was going to do all that he
could was gonna help us out that what he
did with me was kind of experimental and
that he thought that I needed to stay
under his care but that was in December
when the walkers returned to md anderson
for further blood work in late March it
was a different story the doctor came in
and said you know his hands were
basically tied because of the financial
situation that md anderson itself was in
and we would you know the business
office tell me would be be saving a bill
so are you just getting horse feed yeah
how many gonna get Donna and her husband
Russ are currently living on
unemployment checks and occasional
proceeds from a struggling feed store in
suburban Houston you feel like you've
been abandoned you feel like you've been
kicked to the curb you know like as long
as you have insurance we're willing to
go over the moon to see you and make
sure that everything is taken care of
and the minute you don't you're just
they don't want you to make matters
worse Danna learned that according to
federal rules Jake could be denied
coverage for pre-existing conditions if
he goes more than sixty three days
without insurance unable to continue
paying for her previous employers
insurance she scraped together all the
family could afford for a short-term
student health policy through Oklahoma
State University Jake had only a week
left and the cost was 335 dollars a
quarter I mean she came to the store and
said she found this and said I gotta
have the money right now so there was
pills at the store I needed to pay that
didn't get paid but after he graduates
you know say ten years from now god
forbid the cancer comes back and he
can't be covered because I didn't have
the three hundred fifty dollars to cover
him today but the osu policy gives only
temporary relief it expires in mid-may
and provides minimal protection if the
cancer should come back meanwhile a
month behind on the mortgage Donna
continues to look for a job with
benefits you don't realize how fast you
can hit a million dollars you know you
think oh to be a millionaire you'd have
all this money but when you're looking
at medical bills is
Lonmin doesn't take long at all
